subject: Re: [junit] Junit Design Patterns.
msgSnippet: I ve recently revisited ArgoUML (v0.12) and found it to work quite well for creating quick and dirty class diagrams. Import your source files; delete the
messageBody:
I've recently revisited ArgoUML (v0.12) and found it to work quite well for
creating quick and dirty class diagrams.

Import your source files; delete the classes that you're not interested in
seeing; then hit print. Grab the tape dispenser and head for the printer..
:)

I usually end up w/ 3x3 page printouts that I can then color on.

The "Type-Hierarchy" view in Eclipse (&WSAD) can also be very useful to get
a quick idea of what relationships exist.

Regards,
Levi

----- Original Message -----
From: "Dave Astels" <dave@...>
To: "junit list" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, October 11, 2002 10:33 AM
Subject: RE: [junit] Junit Design Patterns.


> On Fri, 2002-10-11 at 14:10, Chappell, Simon P wrote:
>
> > My problem is that no modeling tool yet competes with my whiteboard and
coloured markers.
>
> Ya, no argument there.
>
> Something that'll generate diagrams from code (I use Together.. I worked
> for them for a while) is great for getting clean diagrams for a book or
> article. Even just sketching diagrams for something like that is easier
> in a tool like TCC or Argo, etc. that using something like Visio.
>
> Dave
> --
